curriculum_alignment.nerdc_description: Data organization, databases, networks, cybersecurity essentials

learning_objectives: Differentiate data vs information and describe data quality attributes
Explain how data is organized (files, tables, records, fields) and basic database ideas
Describe network basics (LAN, WAN, internet) and data transmission concepts
Identify common cybersecurity threats and simple protective measures
Apply safe practices relevant to schools, cybercafes, and mobile banking in Nigeria
prerequisites: Awareness of common digital tools (browsers, mobile apps)

content_sections.title: Data vs Information and Data Organization
content_sections.content: **Data**: raw facts; **Information**: processed, meaningful output. Data quality: accuracy, completeness, timeliness, consistency. Organization: character → field → record → file → database. Tables hold rows (records) and columns (fields). Examples: student records, exam scores.

content_sections.title: Databases and File Systems
content_sections.content: File storage vs databases (DBMS) for structured queries and multi-user access. Common DBMS: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQLite. Key terms: primary key, query, table, form, report. Backup importance—use external drives or cloud when available.

content_sections.title: Networks and Data Transmission Basics
content_sections.content: **LAN** (school network), **WAN**, **Internet**. Devices: router, switch, modem, access point. Transmission: wired (Ethernet), wireless (Wi-Fi). IP address identifies devices; bandwidth affects speed; latency affects responsiveness. Nigerian context: mixed reliability; mobile broadband common.

content_sections.title: Cybersecurity Essentials
content_sections.content: Threats: malware (virus, worm, ransomware), phishing (fake emails/SMS), password attacks, unauthorized access, USB-borne malware (common in labs), shoulder surfing. Protections: strong passwords, 2FA, antivirus, software updates, safe browsing, backups, access control, avoid unknown USB drives. Reporting incidents to school IT/teacher.

worked_examples.title: Class List as Table
worked_examples.problem: Show how fields and records are organized.
worked_examples.solution: Table 'Students' with fields: StudentID (PK), Name, Class, Phone. Each row is one student's record.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Phishing
worked_examples.context: SMS claims bank account will be blocked; link provided.
worked_examples.solution: Likely phishing: urgent language, unknown link. Verify via official channels; do not click; report.

worked_examples.title: Backing Up a School Project
worked_examples.context: ICT club project on lab PC only.
worked_examples.solution: Copy to flash drive and cloud (if available); version by date; store offsite; reduces loss from power or malware.

practice_problems.answer: Data: raw facts; Information: processed, meaningful data.

practice_problems.problem: What is a record in a table?
practice_problems.answer: A row containing related fields about one item/person.

practice_problems.problem: State two reasons backups are important.
practice_problems.answer: Protect against hardware failure, malware, accidental deletion, theft.

practice_problems.problem: Differentiate LAN and WAN in one line each.
practice_problems.answer: LAN: local network (school/building). WAN: wide-area network connecting distant sites.

practice_problems.problem: Explain why using unknown USB drives is risky in school labs.
practice_problems.answer: They may carry malware that auto-runs and infects PCs; can spread across lab quickly.

practice_problems.problem: A table has fields: ID, Name, Class, Email. Identify a good primary key.
State two simple steps to secure online banking on a phone.
practice_problems.answer: Use strong PIN/biometrics; enable 2FA/OTP; avoid public Wi-Fi; update apps; log out after use.

practice_problems.problem: Why does low bandwidth cause slow downloads?
practice_problems.answer: Bandwidth limits data per second; lower bandwidth transfers less data over time, increasing download duration.

quick_checks: Give one difference between LAN and WAN.

exam_style_questions.question: Describe three common cybersecurity threats faced by students using public cybercafes and propose one control for each.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Phishing (verify links); keyloggers/malware (antivirus, avoid unknown PCs); shoulder surfing (cover PIN, privacy screens); insecure Wi-Fi (avoid sensitive logins).

exam_style_questions.question: Explain how data should be organized for a school's library system using tables and primary keys, and outline a simple backup approach suitable for limited internet access.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Tables: Books, Students, Loans; PKs: BookID, StudentID, LoanID; backups to external drive weekly; optional cloud when available.
